column4: The parts of this module that work with module names apply the same syntax
that is used for barewords in Perl source.  In principle this syntax

column4: The functions of this module whose purpose is to load modules include
workarounds for three old Perl core bugs regarding C<require>.  These
workarounds are applied on any Perl version where the bugs exist
for a case where one of the bugs cannot be adequately worked around in
The usable module name syntax has not changed from Perl 5.000 up to
Perl 5.19.8.  The syntax is composed entirely of ASCII characters.
From Perl 5.6 onwards there has been some attempt to allow the use of
non-ASCII Unicode characters in Perl source
broken (like the entirety of Perl 5.6's Unicode handling) and remained
pretty much entirely unusable until it got some attention in the Perl
5.15 series.  Although Unicode is now consistently accepted by the

column5: it remains broken for module names.  Furthermore

column4: there has not yet been any work on how to map Unicode module names into

column5: so in that respect also Unicode module names are unusable.
precisely: the string must consist of one or

column4: more segments separated by C<::>; each segment must consist of one or more
identifier characters (ASCII alphanumerics plus "_"); the first character
of the string must not be a digit.  Thus "C<IO::File>"
and "C<foo::123::x_0>" are all valid module names
and "C<1foo::bar>" are not.  C<'> separators are not permitted by this

column5: though they remain usable in Perl source

column4: The first bug worked around is core bug [perl #68590]
lexical state in one file to leak into another that is C<require>d/C<use>d

fixed in Perl 5.11.0.  From Perl 5.9.4 up to Perl 5.10.0 no satisfactory
workaround is possible in pure Perl.  The workaround means that modules
loaded via this module don't suffer this pollution of their lexical
state.  Modules loaded in other ways

The third bug worked around causes the wrong context to be seen at
file scope of a loaded module
column5: if C<require> is invoked in a location
